reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Bono de Desarrollo Humano (BDH)' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Bono de Desarrollo Humano (BDH) is a well-documented conditional cash transfer program in Ecuador targeting poor and extremely poor households, providing regular income support with health and education conditionalities. Multiple sources, including the World Bank and national organizations, consistently describe BDH as a cash transfer program. Its main component is the provision of monetary benefits to beneficiaries, which is explicitly stated in both official and analytical sources[3][4][6][7]. There is no evidence that BDH itself provides productive assets; instead, a related program called 'Cr√©dito de Desarrollo Humano' offers lump-sum loans to promote productive investments and is informally referred to as a 'graduation program' from BDH, but BDH on its own is not designed as a multi-component graduation model that combines cash, asset transfers, training, and other supports[3]. BDH does not have a direct asset transfer component. The related graduation pilot by UNHCR-MIES-HIAS referenced in Ecuador is distinct and targets refugees; it only built upon the cash base of BDH but is not part of BDH itself[2]. | Graduation: NO, Cash: YES, Assets: NO | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://ieg.worldbankgroup.org/evaluations/world-bank-group-ecuador/chapter-4-complementary-support-improved-social-protection, https://grupofaro.org/analisis/bono-de-desarrollo-humano-en-ecuador/, https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/entities/publication/2459916b-62f7-549e-8361-1e5a346ed171
